results.title: The Kawelka Ongka's Big Moka
results.creator_credit: Charles Nairn and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Disappearing world”.
In the West Highlands of Papua New Guinea there are many tribes. One of them is the Kawelka. The most prominent leader or ‘big man’ of the Kawelka tribe is called Ongka. For five years the Kawelka, driven on by Ongka, have been struggling to assemble a huge gift (a Moka) to give to a neighbouring tribe. For Ongka, assembling and giving this gift is more important than anything in his life. But when a big man dies suddenly in Ongka’s enemy tribe things start to go wrong.

results.title: The Wodaabe
results.creator_credit: Leslie Woodhead and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Disappearing world”.
The Wodaabe are among the world’s last true nomads. They follow their herds in an endless migration across African borders. They have no houses, no huts and no tents. They live and sleep under the skies. Although droughts have ravaged their lands since the 1960’s, anthropologist Mette Bovin sees their life as a balance between hardship and joy. They have an obsession with male beauty and Wodaabe men wear more make-up than Wodaabe women. “We like to see people who are handsome” says one. The Wodaabe insist they will remain nomads despite mounting pressures for them to settle down and lead a “normal” life.

results.title: Kataragama: a god for all seasons
results.creator_credit: Charlie Nairn and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Disappearing world”.
The story of how the parents of an eleven-year old Sri Lankan boy consulted an astrologer to help them find their son. The astrologer instructs them to seek help from the god, Kataragama, who correctly forecast the boy would be returned in twenty one days. Shows scenes of worshippers of Kataragama who thank him for favours received by walking through pits of red hot fire. Some hung themselves from butcher’s hooks impaled in their backs.
results.description:

results.creator_credit: Simone West, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: How should we remember Stuart?
results.creator_credit: Kath Ensor, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Speaking for her grandmother, Elizabeth, Kath Ensor remembers her grandfather, Stuart. Encompassing his time serving in the RAAF during World War II, his love for his family and his positive attitude, despite experiencing ill health.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kath Ensor, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.brief_description: These eleven short stories were created as part of a Digital Storytelling workshop in February 2007. They mostly run for less than two minutes and cover diverse subject matter, including treasured family members, life changing events and vocational experiences.

results.title: My university challenge
results.creator_credit: Ray Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ray Martin and his girlfriend enrolled in a university course in Thailand to become qualified English teachers. It was here that Martin set himself a challenge that not many people had been successful at achieving.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ray Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
